column3: He had professed to himself that his reason for not going there was the non performance of the commission which Lady Ongar had given him with reference to Count Pateroff.

column2: He had not yet succeeded in catching the Count, though he had twice asked for him in Mount Street and twice at the club in Pall Mall. It appeared that the Count never went to Mount Street, and was very rarely seen at the club.

column2: He did not dare to trust himself with Lady Ongar.

column2: He felt when there as the accustomed but repentant dram-drinker might feel, when, having resolved to abstain, he is called upon to sit with the full glass offered before his lips.

column2: From such temptations as that the repentant dram-drinker knows that he must fly. But though he did not go after the fire-water of Bolton Street, neither was he able to satisfy himself with the cool fountain of Onslow Crescent.

column2: He was wretched at this time--ill-satisfied with himself and others--and was no fitting companion for Cecilia Burton.

column2: The world, he thought, had used him ill.

column2: He could have been true to Julia Brabazon when she was well-nigh penniless.
column3: He could have been true to Julia Brabazon when she was well nigh penniless.

column2: It was not for her money that he had regarded her.
column3: It was not for her money that he had regarded her.

column2: Had he been now a free man--free from those chains with which he had fettered himself at Stratton--he would again have asked this woman for her love, in spite of her past treachery; but it would have been for her love, and not for her money, that he would have sought her.
column3: Had he been now a free man-free from those chains with which he had fettered himself at Stratton-he would again have asked this woman for her love, in spite of her past treachery; but it would have been for her love, and not for her money, that he would have sought her.

column2: Was it his fault that he had loved her, that she had been false to him, and that she had now come back and thrown herself before him?
column3: Was it his fault that he had loved her, that she had been false to him, and that she had now come back and thrown herself before him?

column2: or had he been wrong because he had ventured to think that he loved another when Julia had deserted him?

column2: Or could he help himself if he now found that his love in truth belonged to her whom he had known first?

column2: Let him write to her, and mention the fact, bringing it up as some little immaterial accident, and she would understand what he meant.

column3: He went about the town very wretchedly, looking for the Count, and regarding himself as a man specially marked out for sorrow by the cruel hand of misfortune.

column2: Sir Hugh Clavering was now in London, and with him was his brother Archie.
column3: Sir Hugh Clavering was now in London, and with him was his brother Archie.

column2: Sir Hugh was a man who strained an income, that was handsome and sufficient for a country gentleman, to the very utmost, wanting to get out of it more than it could be made to give.
column3: Sir Hugh was a man who strained an income, that was handsome and sufficient for a country gentleman, to the very utmost, wanting to get out of it more than it could be made to give.

column2: He was not a man to be in debt, or indulge himself with present pleasures to be paid for out of the funds of future years.
column3: He was not a man to be in debt, or indulge himself with present pleasures to be paid for out of the funds of future years.

column2: He was possessed of a worldly wisdom which kept him from that folly, and taught him to appreciate fully the value of independence.

column2: But he was ever remembering how many shillings there are in a pound, and how many pence in a shilling.

column2: He had a great eye to discount, and looked closely into his bills.

column2: He searched for cheap shops; and some men began to say of him that he had found a cheap establishment for such wines as he did not drink himself!
column3: He searched for cheap shops; and some men began to say of him that he had found a cheap establishment for such wines as he did not drink himself!

column2: In playing cards and in betting, he was very careful, never playing high, never risking much, but hoping to turn something by the end of the year, and angry with himself if he had not done so.
column3: In playing cards and in betting, he was very careful, never playing high, never risking much, but hoping to turn something by the end of the year, and angry with himself if he had not done so.

column2: An unamiable man he was, but one whose heir would probably not quarrel with him--if only he would die soon enough.
column3: An unamiable man he was, but one whose heir would probably not quarrel with him-if only he would die soon enough.

column3: He had always had a house in town-a moderate house in Berkeley Square, which belonged to him, and had belonged to his father before him.

column2: Lady Clavering had usually lived there during the season; or, as had latterly been the case, during only a part of the season.
column3: Lady Clavering had usually lived there during the season; or, as had latterly been the case, during only a part of the season.

column2: And now it had come to pass, in this year, that Lady Clavering was not to come to London at all, and that Sir Hugh was meditating whether the house in Berkeley Square might not be let.
column3: And now it had come to pass, in this year, that Lady Clavering was not to come to London at all, and that Sir Hugh was meditating whether the house in Berkeley Square might not be let.

column2: The arrangement would make the difference of considerably more than a thousand a year to him.

column2: He had no idea of giving up London in the Spring and early Summer.

column2: Chapter XIX
column3: Chapter nineteen

column2: Let Her Know That You're There

column2: The job before him, in his attempt to win Lady Ongar, was a peculiar job, and that Archie well knew.
column3: The job before him, in his attempt to win Lady Ongar, was a peculiar job, and that Archie well knew.

column2: In some inexplicable manner he put himself into the scales and weighed himself, and discovered his own weight with fair accuracy.
column3: In some inexplicable manner he put himself into the scales and weighed himself, and discovered his own weight with fair accuracy.

column2: And he put her into the scales, and he found that she was much the heavier of the two.
column3: And he put her into the scales, and he found that she was much the heavier of the two.

column2: How he did this--how such men as Archie Clavering do do it--I cannot say; but they do weigh themselves, and know their own weight, and shove themselves aside as being too light for any real service in the world.
column3: How he did this-how such men as Archie Clavering do do it-I cannot say; but they do weigh themselves, and know their own weight, and shove themselves aside as being too light for any real service in the world.

column2: This they do, though they may fluster with their voices, and walk about with their noses in the air, and swing their canes, and try to look as large as they may. They do not look large, and they know it; and, consequently, they ring the bells, and look after the horses, and shove themselves on one side, so that the heavier weights may come forth and do the work.
column3: This they do, though they may fluster with their voices, and walk about with their noses in the air, and swing their canes, and try to look as large as they may. They do not look large, and they know it; and, consequently, they ring the bells, and look after the horses, and shove themselves on one side, so that the heavier weights may come forth and do the work.

column2: Archie Clavering, who had duly weighed himself, could hardly bring himself to believe that Lady Ongar would be fool enough to marry him!
column3: Archie Clavering, who had duly weighed himself, could hardly bring himself to believe that Lady Ongar would be fool enough to marry him!

column2: Seven thousand a year, with a park and farm in Surrey, and give it all to him--him, Archie Clavering, who had, so to say, no weight at all!
column3: Seven thousand a year, with a park and farm in Surrey, and give it all to him-him, Archie Clavering, who had, so to say, no weight at all!
